Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Hygroscopicity of Secondary Organic Aerosols Formed via Aqueous Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks better characterization of the climatic impact of a key atmospheric aerosol component, secondary organic aerosol (SOA), which contributes to both natural and anthropogenic aerosol concentrations. The focus is on the impacts of SOA on warm cloud formation. Current models, based on chamber experiments that focused on production of aerosols from gas-phase oxidation processes, tend to underpredict the mass concentrations and the extent of oxygenation of ambient organic aerosols. Growing evidence suggests that SOA formed in clouds or in hydrated haze particles via aqueous reactions (aqSOA) may reconcile these gaps: these aqueous reactions have been shown to proceed under atmospheric conditions in the laboratory, and reaction products are highly oxygenated. Although aqSOA hygroscopicity, a measure of a particle's ability to participate in cloud drop formation or cloud condensation nucleating (CCN) activity, is expected to be high due to its highly oxidized composition, few studies have confirmed this relationship to evaluate its climatic impact. This study will correlate CCN activity of aqSOA, component polarity, and composition for the first time. A new analytical method will be applied for determination of CCN activity of aqSOA as a function of component polarity, providing new insights on the unresolved contribution of many chemical species to overall hygroscopicity. Elemental analysis of aerosol data obtained using a high-resolution time-of-flight aerosol mass spectrometer will be used to evaluate how polarity and hygroscopicity relate to oxygen:carbon ratios in the aerosol phase. The work will be conducted at Colorado State University (CSU) under the mentorship of Prof. Sonia Kreidenweis.

In terms of broader impacts, the results of this project will help improve the global budget of atmospheric organic aerosols and the representation of organic aerosol climate impacts. Also, the principal investigator will be actively involved in educational activities at CSU including serving as a discussion leader for a graduate level course on responsible conduct of research. The principal investigator will also be a research mentor to interns via the NSF-sponsored Center for Multiscale Modeling of Atmospheric Processes at CSU.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Particles in the atmosphere (commonly refereed to as “aerosol” particles) are everywhere, although they are too small to be seen with the naked eye; many of them are hundreds or thousands of times smaller than the width of a human hair. Particulate matter plays important but uncertain roles in human and environmental health and in climate change. Particulate matter is classified as an air pollutant; aerosol layers also act like a sunshade for the earth by reflecting some sunlight back into space and possibly absorbing light as well, and airborne particles serve as the seeds for cloud droplets. A better understanding of where aerosol particles come from, how particles impact clouds - i.e., their ability to act as seeds for cloud droplet and modify cloud and precipitation - and in turn, how clouds impact aerosol, is needed to improve air quality and to mitigate climate change. 


One of the emerging questions over the last decade is the role of atmospheric water in producing aerosol. It is well-known that clouds process many gases and can create particle-phase species; this is the basis for the chemistry of “acid rain”. However, recently it has been shown that clouds can also dissolve organic vapors from the atmosphere, which arise from both natural emissions (e.g., wildfires) and anthropogenic sources (e.g., transportation sources). Water in clouds or wet aerosol may serve as a reactor in the atmosphere, allowing water-soluble organic vapors to participate in liquid-phase chemical reactions leading to formation of atmospheric organic aerosol. Atmospheric chemical reactions of organic compounds in aqueous phase are believed to form highly oxidized organic aerosol; however, how high the ability can be in realistic conditions has remained uncertain. 


This project advanced our understanding of the intricate connections among water, aerosol, and cloud, experimentally and theoretically. A novel experimental technique developed in this study (Nakao et al., Atmos. Meas. Tech., 2014) allows measurement of the ability of particles to become cloud droplets while keeping particles “wet” throughout the analysis, which is a more realistic approach than common techniques that require “dry” particles; for example, drying can evaporate some of the species that would be trapped in the particle phase in the atmosphere. Furthermore, we developed a theoretical framework that clarifies the link between the ability of organic aerosol to support cloud droplet formation and the vapor pressure of the organic components. The theoretical framework coupled with experimental results provided strong evidence to show that the ability of organic aerosol produced by aqueous reactions to become cloud droplets is unlikely to be as high as that of inorganic aerosol, as has been contended. The experimental and theoretical work done during this postdoctoral research may improve the representation of aerosol-cloud interactions in climate and air quality model calculations. 


During the tenure of the AGS postdoctoral research fellowship, the PI, Shunsuke Nakao, had numerous opportunities to interact with students (undergraduate/graduate) within Colorado State University (CSU), as well as outside of CSU.
